captions.text: We live in a three-dimensional world
But what if our world were two-dimensional?
to occupy a single plane of existence,
And what would that world look and feel like?
Flatland is a fun, mathematical thought experiment
that follows the trials and tribulations of a square
But what is a dimension, anyway?
For our purposes, a dimension is a direction,
which we can picture as a line.
For our direction to be a dimension,
it has to be at right angles to all other dimensions.
So, a one-dimensional space is just a line.
and the world we're familiar with.
Where do we put these new perpendicular lines?
This is where Flatland can help us.
Let's look at our square protagonist's world.
Flatland is populated by geometric shapes,
all the way up to circles.
These shapes are all scurrying around a flat world,
They have a single eye on the front of their faces,
and let's see what the world looks like
What they see is essentially one dimension,
and that's how they see depth.
So a triangle looks different from a square,
Their brains cannot comprehend the third dimension.
In fact, they vehemently deny its existence
because it's simply not part of their world
One day a sphere shows up in Flatland
when the sphere passes through Flatland
and this blows his little square mind.
Then the sphere lifts the square
the height direction where no Flatlander has gone before
From up here, the square can see everything:
all the precious gems hidden in the Earth,
and even the insides of his friends,
comes to terms with the third dimension,
he begs his host to help him
visit the fourth and higher dimensions,
but the sphere bristles at the mere suggestion
and exiles the square back to Flatland.
Now, the sphere's indignation is understandable.
A fourth dimension is very difficult
to reconcile with our experience of the world.
Short of being lifted into the fourth dimension
You'll recall that when the sphere
he looked like a series of circles
grew bigger until he was halfway through,
We can think of this visit
as a series of 2D cross-sections of a 3D object.
Well, we can do the same thing
in the third dimension with a four-dimensional object.
is the 4D equivalent of a 3D sphere.
When the 4D object passes through the third dimension,
Let's look at one more way
Let's say we have a point,
Now we extend it out one inch
and we have a one-dimensional line segment.
Extend the whole line segment by an inch,
Take the whole square and extend it out one inch,
You can see where we're going with this.
and extend it out one inch,
this time perpendicular to all three existing directions,
and wondering what all the fuss is about.
In fact, there could be whole
by the nature of our perception.
Doesn't that blow your little spherical mind?

title: Exploring other dimensions - Alex Rosenthal and George Zaidan

comments.author: melody brown

comments.text:
"THE 4TH DIMENSION" is a misleading term in itself, but I hope to settle 
confusion over its flexible meaning by introducing context.  
Dimensions are abstractions that we use to organize coordinates of a 
system.  
A system can use any number of dimensions to represent whatever scalars and 
vectors we need them to model.  
When we describe the physical world, it is convention to attribute the 
first 3 to geometric space, and a 4th to time (when the model requires it), 
but in reality they are not numbered in any set order.  
Time is only "THE 4TH DIMENSION" in the context of common XYZT time-space 
models.  
Sometimes 4D is just a marketing term for a novel feature, like 
"experience".  
"THE 4TH DIMENSION" has no meaning until you establish the context of the 
system that is numbering it.﻿

comments.author: Carson King

comments.text:
From what i understand the 4d is time. Dimensions go in right angles of 
each other. 1d goes one direction then back like a line. 2d goes 4 
directions on a flat plane (e.g. left, right, forward and back). 3d goes 
left, right, forward, back, up and down. The 4th dimension is going forward 
and backwards in time. Time is like a bunch of 3d frames of us occurring 
sort of like a flip book. ( e.g. tesseract). We only see a frame of a 
moment at a time, a cross section of time. A 4d person can see all the 
frames from beginning to end at the same time. Time no longer becomes an 
obstacle it becomes a direction.﻿

The most interesting thing about 4D creatures is that they probably are 
much smarter due to the simple fact that in a higher dimensional space you 
can "fit" much more in the same "space" as you can in lower dimensional 
spaces.
For example, the brain of a 2D creature would have to be much much larger 
than ours to fit the same amount of neurons and synapses that we have.﻿

In a flatland, where there is no height, the flatlanders would see nothing. 
They would not see each other as lines, because these lines cannot have a 
thickness since there is no height. A line with the thickness of zero is 
invisible. That also means a flatlander could not see a part of the 
3-dimensional sphere. And that is why the Tesseract is not really a 
4-dimensional object as long it is displayed in a 3-dimensional space. It 
surely works in theoretical mathematics, but mathematics can only describe 
the sructures of a "reality".﻿

+terastio xtapodi That is the most ignorant thing I've heard.


Go back a step from where you are. When he extends the 2d rectangle to 3d. 
Now look at the 3d cube without imagining the depth (key word: imagining) 
and you'll just see a 2d object, a polygon. Keep in mind it is a 2d object 
and will always be. It's only our perception that is able to visualize it 
in 3d.


Now move forward to when he extends the 3d object to 4d. It still is a 2d 
object (or a 3d object if you imagine it too). But since we have a limited 
perception we simply can't imagine that 4d object. A 4d being would be able 
to visualize that object in 4d just as we would be able to imagine a 3d 
cube drawing in 3d even though it's still 2d.

comments.author: leqesai

comments.text:
+Bullpup The issues you are concerned with seem, more or less, to do with 
the semantics of this issue rather than the general concept+argument (which 
is what I am speaking to). The prisoners perceiving in 2D or 3D was never 
at issue here. The similarities between the argument and this video exist 
wholly in the separation of world-view, the reanalysis of that view, and 
the lack of understanding that comes when an attempt is made to re-educate 
others to the information found in the new world-view (the specifics of The 
Allegory of the Cave exist to make this point a valid argument and could be 
swapped out for other hypothetical situations ad-infinitum).
comments.author: leqesai

comments.text:
+leqesai Hey, as a Mechanical Engineering Major and Philosophy Minor, I 
believe i can shed some light.

Its important to know the context, in *The Republic*, Plato mentions that 
these are actually prisoners chained and made to see only the shadows, then 
one is released and allowed to see what else exists and tell the other 
prisoners about it while a new prisoner is brought, so on. The Prisoners 
ARE 3D but perceive in 2D, second, they are *forced* to perceive in 2D. 
While a real 2D object, perceives in 2D because it IS in 2D, there is no 
force and the only difference from 2D to 3D is a single right angle.
comments.author: Bullpup

comments.text: Thanks for elaborating on your perspective.
comments.author: leqesai

comments.text:
I see your point, but you must understand that mathematics and philosophy 
are highly intertwined- many of the greatest philosophers were 
mathematicians, and vice versa, and in a way, all mathematics and 
philosophy are derived from what came before. I agree with you that the 
idea of Flatland could be seen as a derivation of the Allegory of the Cave, 
but perhaps not to the extent you do, as it is far more preoccupied with 
mathematics than the original idea.
comments.author: S. Smith

comments.text:
+S. Smith The men in the cave only saw the shadows though. The shadows, to 
them, were the entirety of the perceivable world. These men have only 
existed inside the cave and so have no understanding of a world outside the 
cave. This is why, when their friend tells them of the outside world, they 
are unable to conceptualize and believe that something exists outside of 
what they know. The idea expressed in this video derives heavily from this 
as the 2D objects interact with the 3D objects and the 3D objects fail to 
recognize or believe in 4D objects.

Granted, the video isn't like a retelling of the Allegory of the Cave but 
it is highly derivative.
comments.author: leqesai

comments.text:
+leqesai Well, for one Plato's thought experiment relied on the prisoners 
perceiving the shadows that the world cast, while in Flatland the shapes 
were perceiving the world itself.

comments.text:
For people that are having a hard time understanding this: The other way of 
"picturing" higher dimensions, would be like saying all dimension could be 
represented by a scale or line that goes from say 0 to 100 or why not, 
-infinity to (plus) infinity. And to say when/where something is in said 
dimension you would need a number to describe it.

For a line you just need 1 number, think of a linear coordinate system, or 
when you say something is x meters long. The more dimensions you add the 
more numbers you need to tell the sate of said object. If you have 2 
dimensions you need 2 numbers. Think of a chess board, or a game of "sink" 
the ship". For 3 dimensions, you would add a number for the height.
Now a fourth dimension can not be represented in our 3-dimensional space, 
because geometrically there is no direction at a right angle to all other 
directions. So lets say as before we represent it with a number.
Then, you could for example say in which state your object is in a 4-th 
dimension without having to picture it.
If we say time is another dimension we could say in which state we are with 
4 numbers. But of course, we can already do that, "I'm at x place at said 
time". The problem is you cannot picture any higher dimensions 
geometrically, and you probably never will. It's just though fodder, but 
mathematically, you do can study them, which is nice :)﻿

I disagree. Practically every single thing is in the space of 3 dimensions. 
In theory we can think of flat objects as 2D or something like it, just 
because thats how we define and explain stuff when designing objects. But 
practically any kind of shape is 3D. Even your 2D printed plastic rectangle 
is 3D physically since the depth of it need's to be at least 1 atom 
physically. Every physical item in the real world is 3D. Even this nasty 
hyper cube is 3D to me. I seen loads of explanations of 4D and such, but 
space wise its bollox.﻿
comments.author: Karolis Marksaitis

comments.text:
+David Linderman I am not running on the asumption. Everything we do is in 
3D. We draw, see and move in 3D space. Everything works in 3D. Finding some 
strange correlations between physical atoms situated in our 3D environment 
doesn't make something 4D just because of that. It is stupid to call it 4th 
dimension because it doesn't have same properties as 2nd and 3rd dimensions 
themselves. It's completely different.
comments.author: Karolis Marksaitis

comments.text:
+Karolis Marksaitis You are running on the assumption that matter is 3D, 
which is challenged by newer theoretical models. So physical models are not 
even 3D per se, but more like multidimensional particles organized by 3D 
configurations.

moved along on a 1D line. Amazing, right?

comments.author: trueandonlyfandre

comments.text:
Or we live in more dimensions than we realize (or there is only 3 
dimensions)

Our perspective of 2D is still 3D at least.  So maybe there really is no 4 
dimensions, but rather it all comes down to how we look at it instead.  

For something to be 1 or 2 dimensional, is technically impossible.  That 
flat square has to have height, otherwise it functionally has zero data, 
and zero interaction, meaning it doesn't exist.  After all, in order to 
even discern another '2D' object in a 2D world, the object has to have a 
top and a bottom to discern what it is from the side.  If it doesn't, then 
it effectively has zero volume, and again, does not exist.....even to other 
2D objects....which also wouldn't exist anyways....and in fact, can not 
exist, even outside of the sense of us perceiving it or not.  

No one has yet to say exactly what effect or property the 4th dimension 
could be having, other than it's defined by some extra volume in some 
direction. Well, every direction is possible in space, so exactly what 
direction is this extra dimension going?  On top of that, what type of 
matter is filling this direction, and how is it interacting with the other 
3 directions?  

After all, anything in 4 dimension, would have to be anchored in 3 
dimensions.

Let's say for example, gravity is a result of the 4th dimension.  But in 
the end, all it is, is a property of matter, in 3 dimensions.  

One issue is we would most likely be observing more unexplained actions, 
since all 3D matter would be routed in 4D.  for example, if you slid a 3D 
cube across the table, it would still appear to move to the 2D 
object.....seemingly on its own. ﻿

comments.author: randomhalofan292

comments.text:
+Tara Strong from what i understand the 4d is time. Dimensions go in right 
angles of each other. 1d goes one direction then back like a line. 2d goes 
4 directions on a flat plane (e.g. left, right, forward and back). 3d goes 
left, right, forward, back, up and down. The 4th dimension is going forward 
and backwards in time. Time is like a bunch of 3d frames of us occurring 
sort of like a flip book. ( e.g. tesseract). We only see a frame at a time, 
a cross section of time. A 4d person can see all the frames from beginning 
to end at once. Time no longer becomes an obstacle it becomes a direction.

Right... It has no height, therefore it would not be able to see anything 
else in their plane at all. The concept of 'sight' would not even exist for 
something in that plane. That's why this is nothing more than a thought 
experiment - but the thought experiment always has to revert to using 
height to express how it would work... Which sort of defeats the purpose of 
expressing how lifeforms in 2D would perceive reality.

comments.text:
"This time perpendicular to all three existing directions". with no concern 
for right angles or 90 degrees. i believe this is where the claim falls 
apart.

 earlier in the video it claims to need 90 degree right angle changes for a 
change in dimension. 

So how can you get a 4th dimension out of breaking a rule that applies to 
all other dimensions.

Seems to me you get 3 obvious directions that follow the 90 degree right 
angle rules. Then you claim to be able to move perpendicular clearly 
violating the 90 degree right angle. seems you are still operating in 3 
dimensions and trying to make special circumstance.

Am I wrong here? The whole move the box thing to get 4th dimension seems.. 
well it seems like a leap of faith. as you provided no 90 degree right 
angle. you just moved perpendicular.

Granted i am probably missing something.. but it seems once the 4d shit 
starts it is a bunch of leaps with no actual fact.﻿

like the wire model at 4:10.
